question: Question_08_(d)
statement:
Let $\displaystyle y = f(x) = 63x^{2/7}-14x^{9/7}$. Sketch the graph of
$\displaystyle y=f(x)$ and indicate the inflection point(s) on your
graph. (The results from parts
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH100/December_2013/Question_08_(a)}{(a)},
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH100/December_2013/Question_08_(b)}{(b)},
and
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH100/December_2013/Question_08_(c)}{(c)}
may be useful.)
sols:
From parts
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH100/December_2013/Question_08_(a)}{(a)},
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH100/December_2013/Question_08_(b)}{(b)},
and
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH100/December_2013/Question_08_(c)}{(c)}
we know the following about $f(x) = 63x^{2/7}-14x^{9/7}$:

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  The \textbf{critical numbers} of $f$ (where $f'$ is zero or does not
  exist) are $\displaystyle x = 0, 1$
\item
  $f$ is \textbf{increasing} on $x \in (0,1)$ and \textbf{decreasing} on
  $x \in (-\infty,0) \cup (1, \infty)$
\item
  $f$ has a \textbf{local minimum} at $\displaystyle x = 0$ and a
  \textbf{local maximum} at $\displaystyle x = 1$ (note the change in
  the increase/decrease of $f$)
\item
  $f$ is \textbf{concave up} on $x \in (-\infty,-\tfrac{5}{2})$ and
  \textbf{concave down} on $x \in (-\tfrac{5}{2},0) \cup (0, \infty)$
\item
  $f$ has an \textbf{inflection point} (changes concavity) at
  $x = -\tfrac{5}{2}$
\end{itemize}

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $\displaystyle f(x) = x^{\frac{2}{7}} (63 - 14x)$ and thus $f$ has
  \emph{x}-intercepts at $x = 0, \tfrac{9}{2}$
\end{itemize}

\begin{itemize}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  $\lim_{x \to 0^-} f'(x) = -\infty$ and
  $\lim_{x \to 0^+} f'(x) = \infty$, thus the graph of $f$ is very steep
  near $x = 0$
\end{itemize}

hints:
What are the \textbf{critical numbers} of $f$? What are the intervals of
\textbf{increase/decrease} of $f$? How do these relate to the
\emph{extrema} of $f$?

What are the intervals of \textbf{concavity} of $f$? What is an
\textbf{inflection point}, and how does it relate to \emph{concavity}?

It may be useful to find the \emph{x}-intercept(s) of $\displaystyle f$.
In addition, note the behaviour of $\displaystyle f'$ near $x = 0$.
